Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Strengthening Wi-Fi Network Wide

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wi-Fi has emerged as the technology of choice for Internet access. Thus, virtually every smartphone or tablet is now equipped with a Wi-Fi card. Concurrently, and as a means to maximize spectral efficiency, Wi-Fi radios are becoming increasingly complex and sensitive to wireless channel conditions. The prevalence of Wi-Fi networks, along with their adaptive behaviors, makes them an ideal target for denial of service attacks at a large, infrastructure level.

This project aims to comprehensively investigate the resiliency of Wi-Fi networks to smart attacks, and to design and implement robust solutions capable of resisting or countering them. The project additionally focuses on harnessing new capabilities of Wi-Fi radios, such as multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) antennas, to protect against powerful adversaries. The research blends theory with experimentation and prototyping, and spans a range of disciplines including protocol design and analysis, coding and modulation, on-line algorithms, queuing theory, and emergent behaviors.

The anticipated benefits of the project include: (1) a deep understanding of threats facing Wi-Fi along several dimensions, via experiments and analysis; (2) a set of mitigation techniques and algorithms to strengthen existing Wi-Fi networks and emerging standards; (3) implementation into open-source software that can be deployed on wireless network cards and access points; (4) security training of the next-generation of scientists and engineers involved in radio design and deployment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The U.S. economy largely depends on wireless communication technologies, and in particular Wi-Fi, to fuel its growth. During the challenging times of the COVID-19 pandemic, computers and smartphone with Wi-Fi connectivity have allowed many Americans to work from home, stay in touch with family, friends, and co-workers, and maintain social distancing.

Crucially, Wi-Fi devices achieve high performance by sensing the radio frequency (RF) environment and accordingly adapting their physical parameters (e.g., center frequency, bit rate, and modulation). This adaptive behavior raises risks, however, as it makes Wi-Fi devices vulnerable to targeted, yet stealthy, attacks on their availability and reliability.

This project aimed to comprehensively investigate the resiliency of Wi-Fi networks (and other related wireless technologies) to sophisticated attacks, and to design and implement robust solutions capable of resisting or countering these attacks. The research blended theory with experimentation and prototyping, and consisted of three main thrusts: vulnerability assessment, modeling, and counter-measures.

Intellectual Merit

1) We unveiled the existence of a vulnerability in the IEEE 802.11 standard, which allows an attacker to launch protocol-compliant cascading DoS attacks. In contrast to existing jamming attacks, the attacker does not need to be in the vicinity of the victims. We demonstrated the attack through experiments on a testbed composed of nodes equipped with real Wi-Fi cards, and through extensive ns-3 simulations for a realistic indoor building model. The preliminary findings of this research were presented at the IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (CNS) 2016, where the accompanying paper was awarded “best paper”.

2) We demonstrated that a DoS attack is feasible even under high Signal-to-Interference Ratio (SIR). The attack leverages a property of the physical layer of Wi-Fi, called "receiver capture" effect. We demonstrated the existence of the receiver capture effect through experiments on real Wi-Fi cards.

3) We developed a control-theoretic framework to determine the stability (or lack thereof) of Wi-Fi networks under attacks. Using this framework, we uncovered a phase transition phenomenon. When the packet generation rate of the attacker is lower than the phase transition point, it has vanishing effect on the rest of the network. However, once the packet generation rate exceeds the phase transition point, the network becomes entirely congested. We developed an analytical model that sheds light into the phase transition observed in the simulations and experiments.

4) We devised a countermeasure to alleviate the impact of cascading DoS attacks. The approach is based on shortening the duration of packet transmissions. We demonstrated the effectiveness of our countermeasures through theoretical analysis, actual experiments on a testbed, and simulation. We also showed that our countermeasure is more efficient than the standard RTS/CTS method, especially at high bit rates.

In addition to the above, we conducted investigation on strengthening the security and privacy of wireless technologies closely related to Wi-Fi, namely networks of connected vehicles (based on the DSRC IEEE 802.11p standard) and Bluetooth networks. Our main results were as follows:

5) We demonstrated that state-of-the-art Bluetooth devices implementing MAC address randomization can be tracked, due to implementation flaws. We offered countermeasures to defend against these and other privacy flaws in Bluetooth advertising. These results are particularly relevant in the context of COVID-19 contact tracing apps based on Bluetooth.

6) We developed and validated new methods to detect misbehavior in networks of connected vehicles. Our methods are based on measuring the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) of incoming packets and are effective even if the majority of nodes in the network are misbehaving.

Broader Impacts

This project contributed to the protection of the electromagnetic spectrum, by training the next-generation of scientists and engineers involved in the design and deployment of radio communication. Thus, three Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students were trained on the theoretical and experimental aspects of resilient communication in the presence of adversaries.

In addition, the PI reinstated and completed redesigned the undergraduate course on Communication Systems (EC415) offered by the ECE Department at Boston University. In particular, he designed an entire sequence of labs through which students learn about programming software radios using the open-source GNU radio ecosystem.

This project contributed to the development of theoretical, simulation, and experimental models to characterize the vulnerabilities of wireless networks to cascading DoS attacks. We developed queueing-theoretic and control-theoretic models to understand and mitigate these attacks. We also contributed new libraries to the open-source ns-3 simulator, which have been shared with the community.
